thread.title: Today’s Top Supply Chain and Logistics News From - WSJ
thread.title_full: Today’s Top Supply Chain and Logistics News From WSJ - WSJ

author: Paul Page
title: Today’s Top Supply Chain and Logistics News From - WSJ
text:
0 COMMENTS Sign up: With one click, get this newsletter delivered to your inbox .
The merger of China’s two biggest shipping companies is looking more like a reality. The WSJ’s Costas Paris reports that China Ocean Shipping Co. and China Shipping Group Co. are in advanced talks toward building a single carrier with business ranging from $15 billion to more than $20 billion , and focusing on the companies’ container lines. A merger would have a seismic impact on global shipping, creating the world’s fourth-biggest container operator with 8% of total capacity. A tie-up could also touch off a new wave of consolidation, a step many in the shipping industry believe is long overdue as it would make it easier to reduce capacity and lift rates from rock-bottom levels. It could also spark a game of musical chairs among members of the big shipping alliances, as Cosco and China Shipping belong to rival groups.
A high-stakes battle is underway inside the Apple Inc. AAPL -1.41 % supply chain . Two of Apple’s biggest suppliers— Advanced Semiconductor Engineering Inc. ASX 3.05 % and Hon Hai Precision Industry Co. 2317 0.70 % , known as Foxconn—are fighting for control of a third company that is developing a a key technology used in the latest iPhones and smartwatches . The WSJ’s Lorraine Luk writes that billions of dollars in potential revenue and new orders from Apple hang in the balance as shareholders of Siliconware Precision Industries Co. SPIL 2.41 % , or SPIL, consider competing offers. ASE and Foxconn already are major suppliers to Apple, and their conflict underscores the big weight Apple’s business carries in their current operations and their plans. Apple probably will end up the real winner no matter which company works with SPIL since any tie-up is likely to drive down production costs and give Apple more supplier options.
Wal-Mart Stores Inc. WMT -10.04 % is betting big on the future of e-commerce , but the present is looking increasingly ugly. The retail giant predicted a sharp drop in earnings next year, largely due to plans to raise wages for U.S. workers but also because of major outlays to boost the company’s online presence , the WSJ’s Sarah Nassauer and Lisa Beilfuss report. Wal-Mart is well-positioned to compete with Amazon.com AMZN -0.74 % and other online retailers because of its size and global footprint, but building the logistics infrastructure takes time and money. The WSJ’s Kim S. Nash reports the retailer will spend $2 billion over the next two years on work that will include the addition of four dedicated fulfillment centers aimed at serving online customers while keeping the supply chain for brick-and-mortar stores running.
SUPPLY CHAIN STRATEGIES ENLARGE Federal-Mogul says a more efficient supply chain can be a boon to the inventory-heavy auto parts industry. Photo: Federal-Mogul Motorparts The auto-parts business used to be all about efficient production , but Federal-Mogul Holdings Corp. FDML 0.75 % says the supply chain now is the difference-maker. The WSJ’s Jeff Bennett reports that the motor parts giant has overhauled its operations to respond to changes in the automobile industry , highlighting the dramatic shifts that competition is triggering in a seemingly unbending industrial business. A proliferation of car models has created a ”complex jungle” of an auto market and the push by owners to keep cars on the road longer means more new parts are needed for repairs. Federal-Mogul is bringing in new technology, both to face customers and to better manage its sprawling inventory. The business will add two warehouses to the four it already runs, but they’ll operate those more efficiently and even add the robotic handling systems pioneered by Amazon.com.
Uber Technologies Inc. now is officially in the delivery business , and not just testing the waters. But the impact of the courier service called UberRush is far from certain. The WSJ’s Douglas MacMillan writes that the smartphone-enabled courier service that was tested in New York also will be available to local merchants in Chicago and San Francisco , building out what Uber calls its “urban logistics network.” Uber has discovered, however, that moving goods like flowers and food can be more complex and costly than moving passengers that, after all, can get themselves to and from vehicles. The WSJ’s Laura Stevens writes that FedEx Corp. FDX -0.50 % and United Parcel Service Inc. aren’t likely to see much threat to their sprawling operations that handle some 25 million parcels each day.
Delta Air Lines Inc. gave a grim view of the air freight market as the carrier kicked off airline earnings season. Delta’s cargo revenue fell 20% in the third quarter , reports the WSJ’s Doug Cameron, as West Coast ports bounced back from slowdowns earlier in the year. By now it’s clear that ports will mount a near-total recovery after losing business during the worst of the congestion at the start of 2015. Alternative carriers, ranging from airlines to trucking companies to railroads, are giving back ground they had hoped to have permanently gained. Airlines can only hope that the U.S. economy picks up, increasing freight volumes for all.
QUOTABLE
‘ You have to have the right part at the right place at the right time or you lose the sale. We have to make sure they never lose the sale. ’
—Dan Ninivaggi, Federal-Mogul Holdings.
AN INVITATION The WSJ Logistics Report’s Robbie Whelan and Brian Baskin will have a live Q&A on the trucking industry and their recent story on driver recruiting on Thursday at 2 p.m. Eastern time. You can join the conversation on Facebook .
You can also catch them Thursday morning on the SiriusXM satellite radio show, Freewheelin’, on Road Dog Trucking, Channel 146.
IN OTHER NEWS Australian officials are raising concerns over a deal to have a Chinese company manage the port at Darwin , near a military training site with the closest access to disputed South China Sea waters. (WSJ)
J.B. Hunt Transport Services Inc., JBHT 3.26 % expanded its profit 13% to $194 million , with more demand for intermodal shipping containers leading the growth. (WSJ)
CSX Corp. is reducing head count 6% and running longer trains to cut costs in line with lower carload demand. (WSJ)
A key U.S. freight volume measure hit its lowest September level in at least three years , suggesting heavily-stocked retailers are curtailing orders. (WSJ)
The U.S. economy continued a “modest expansion” in the third quarter, the Federal Reserve said. (WSJ)
Whole Foods Market Inc. will work with technology firm Infor Inc. to build a retail management system that brings better supply chain visibility . (WSJ)
Hapag-Lloyd AG set out details for the $410 million initial public offering the German shipping company plans this month. (WSJ)
The dollar fell to multi-week lows on world markets on news of weak retail sales. (WSJ)
Nike Inc. projects it will reach $50 billion in revenue by 2020, partly by doubling sales of women’s apparel. (WSJ)
IKEA will sharply increase its investment in e-commerce in the next five years. (CNBC)
A United Nations report says shipping industry consolidation is eliminating competition in smaller countries. (Reuters)
Container ship operators are idling vessels at a faster rate. (JOC)
Real estate firms and retailers are altering construction strategies to meet same-day delivery demands. (The Street)
International Container Terminal Services Inc. plans to open three terminals next year , even as the operator reduces capital spending. (Philippine Star)
Thai consumer-products seller Saha Group will work with Japanese logistics operator Seino Holdings to offer distribution services . (Nikkei)
Earnings for very large crude carriers have soared past $100,000 a day . (Seatrade)
Abercrombie & Fitch Co. will invest heavily in a mobile e-commerce strategy to win back customers. (Digiday)
ABOUT US Paul Page is deputy editor of WSJ Logistics Report. Follow him at @PaulPage , and follow the entire WSJ Logistics Report team: @brianjbaskin , @lorettachao , @RWhelanWSJ and @EEPhillips_WSJ , and follow the WSJ Logistics Report on Twitter at @WSJLogistics .
